content.description: Climb the highly featured face to the left of "Jennifer's Crack" to a two bolt anchor.  Easy climbing with tricky gear.
content.protection: Small wires, tcu'c, tricams and trickery.  Arrange pro in the pockets and seams of the face as needed.  Don't pass up a good placement, there aren't a lot of them.  Makes a good top rope route if your not up to the lead.

content.description:
This is one of the better routes in the area. 

  Start in a right-facing corner, aiming for a bolt about 15' up.  Clip the bolt (use a runner), and traverse left on interesting finger pockets.  A red TCU protects this section getting to the second bolt.  Sustained pocket pulling will see you to the chains.  Enjoy.
content.protection: Slings, draws, and a red TCU.
content.location: To the left of the slab right is a right-facing corner with a bolt about 15' up.  Climb to the bolt and traverse left.

content.description: This is a somewhat fun route with lots of loose rock and some marginal gear.  Start up the deep crack placing a couple of large cams before the roof.  Pull the roof with the occasional stem and jam before reaching the anchor.
content.protection: Bring large gear.  I can't remember the specifics.  Make sure to bring some cord for the anchor, as the bolts a pretty far apart.
content.location: This ascends the deep crack to the right of The Razor's Edge.  A distinct V-slot roof helps identify it.

content.description: This is a unique route for the area.  It has consistently difficult moves to the top on interesting quartz crystals.  It is well-protected the whole way.
content.location: This is the furthest route to the right.

content.description: This striking arete feature will likely be the first thing you notice.  A hard move off the ground leads to a spectacular section of barn door laybacks.  Finish up on cruiser jugs to a two bolt anchor.  There is an enjoyable variation that breaks left to the anchor of Karen's Crack.  Make sure to bring a couple runners for this.
content.location: It ascends the obvious arete edge.  There is a nice belay platform to take in the view.

content.description:
This is a fun moderate for the area on good rock. 

  Start up a low angled slab to reach the business.  There are really good layback moves on bomber jugs for the majority of the route.  Cool!
content.protection: I only placed one #4 down low and a #1 in a horizontal about 3/4 of the way up.  Bigger gear would be required to make it a safe lead.
content.location: This is to the left of The Razors Edge up the obvious wide crack.

content.description: Follow the obvious crack in a corner past a bolt.  The original route did not use this bolt.  Pull a small roof on good holds.  Climb the short face above the roof to a 2 bolt anchor.
content.protection: Trad gear to #2 Cam.  TCU or smaller gear can be used to protect the roof and the face above if needed.

content.description: Start out with a short boulder problem with tricky feet.  Gain the ledge past the first bolt and traverse left out on to the pocket face.  Continue up the featured face to the anchors.
content.protection: Bolts to a two bolt anchor.
content.location: Second route to the right from the obvious bolted edge ("Razor Edge").

content.description: You better believe it!  27 mile crag is the place you want to be on a sunny afternoon.  Stunning mountain and glacier views make this place dreamy.  The rock here is quite good compared to some of the other choss piles around.  This is probably my favorite place to climb in the Valdez area.  Sweet!
